Emacs commands generally involve the CONTROL key (sometimes labeled
CTRL or CTL) or the META key (sometimes labeled EDIT or ALT).  Rather than
write that in full each time, we'll use the following abbreviations:[8;2HC-<chr>  means hold the CONTROL key while typing the character <chr>
          Thus, C-f would be: hold the CONTROL key and type f.
 M-<chr>  means hold the META or EDIT or ALT key down while typing <chr>.[11;11HIf there is no META, EDIT or ALT key, instead press and release the
          ESC key and then type <chr>.  We write <ESC> for the ESC key.

Important note: to end the Emacs session, type C-x C-c.  (Two characters.)
To quit a partially entered command, type C-g.[K
The characters ">>" at the left margin indicate directions for you to
try using a command.  For instance:
[K
>> Now type C-v (View next screen) to move to the next screen.
	(go ahead, do it by holding down the CONTROL key while typing v).
        From now on, you should do this again whenever you finish
        reading the screen.[K[23;6H[7m----F1  [0m[39;49m[27m[7m[1mTUTORIAL    [0m[39;49m[27m[7m   Top L1   [0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25l        From now on, you should do this again whenever you finish
	reading the screen.
[K
Note that there is an overlap of two lines when you move from screen[K
to screen; this provides some continuity so you can continue reading
the text.
[K
The first thing that you need to know is how to move around from place
to place in the text.  You already know how to move forward one screen,[K
with C-v.  To move backwards one screen, type M-v (hold down the META key[K
and type v, or type <ESC>v if you do not have a META, EDIT, or ALT key).

>> Try typing M-v and then C-v, a few times.[K

>> Find the cursor, and note what text is near it.  Then type C-l.[K
   Find the cursor again and notice that the same text is still near[K

   the screen.  Press C-l again, and it moves to the bottom.

You can also use the PageUp and PageDn keys to move by screenfuls, if
your terminal has them, but you can edit more efficiently if you use
C-v and M-v.

[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25l* BASIC CURSOR CONTROL
----------------------[K
[K
Moving from screenful to screenful is useful, but how do you
move to a specific place within the text on the screen?
[K
There are several ways you can do this.  You can use the arrow keys,
but it's more efficient to keep your hands in the standard position
and use the commands C-p, C-b, C-f, and C-n.  These characters[K
are equivalent to the four arrow keys, like this:[K
[K[13;4H                       Previous line, C-p[K[14;4H                               :[K
 :
   Backward, C-b .... Current cursor position .... Forward, C-f[K
                                  :[K
                                  :[19;29HNext line, C-n

>> Move the cursor to the line in the middle of that diagram
   using C-n or C-p.  Then type C-l to see the whole diagram[23;30H[7m5% L58[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25l>> Move the cursor to the line in the middle of that diagram
   using C-n or C-p.  Then type C-l to see the whole diagram[4;4Hcentered in the screen.
[K
You'll find it easy to remember these letters by words they stand for:
P for previous, N for next, B for backward and F for forward.  You
will be using these basic cursor positioning commands all the time.[K

When you move past the top or bottom of the screen, the text beyond
the edge shifts onto the screen.  This is called "scrolling".  It
enables Emacs to move the cursor to the specified place in the text
without moving it off the screen.[K

following word.  M-b works likewise in the opposite direction.

You can also move the cursor with the arrow keys, if your terminal has
arrow keys.  We recommend learning C-b, C-f, C-n and C-p for thre
reasons.  First, they work on all kinds of terminals.  Second, once[K
you gain practice at using Emacs, you will find that typing these Control
characters is faster than typing the arrow keys (because you do not
have to move your hands away from touch-typing position).  Third, once
you form the habit of using these Control character commands, you can
easily learn to use other advanced cursor motion commands as well.
[K
Most Emacs commands accept a numeric argument; for most commands, this
serves as a repeat-count.  The way you give a command a repeat count
is by typing C-u and then the digits before you type the command.  If[K
you have a META (or EDIT or ALT) key, there is another, alternative way[23;30H[7m5% L183[0m[39;49m[27m[12;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25lis by typing C-u and then the digits before you type the command.  If
you have a META (or EDIT or ALT) key, there is another, alternative way
to enter a numeric argument: type the digits while holding down the
META key.  We recommend learning the C-u method because it works on
any terminal.  The numeric argument is also called a "prefix argument",
because you type the argument before the command it applies to.
[K
For instance, C-u 8 C-f moves forward eight characters.
[K
>> Try using C-n or C-p with a numeric argument, to move the cursor
   to a line near this one with just one command.[K
[K
Most commands use the numeric argument as a repeat count, but some[K
commands use it in some other way.  Several commands (but none of[K
those you have learned so far) use it as a flag--the presence of a[K
prefix argument, regardless of its value, makes the command do[K
something different.
[K
C-v and M-v are another kind of exception.  When given an argument,[K
they scroll the text up or down by that many lines, rather than by a[K
screenful.  For example, C-u 8 C-v scrolls by 8 lines.[K[23;30H[7m7% L192[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lthey scroll the text up or down by that many lines, rather than by a[K
screenful.  For example, C-u 8 C-v scrolls by 8 lines.[K
[K
>> Try typing C-u 8 C-v now.[K
[K
This should have scrolled the text up by 8 lines.  If you would like
to scroll it down again, you can give an argument to M-v.
[K
If you are using a graphical display, such as X or MS-Windows, there
should be a tall rectangular area called a scroll bar on one side of
the Emacs window.  You can scroll the text by clicking the mouse in
the scroll bar.
[K
If your mouse has a wheel button, you can also use this to scroll.

* IF EMACS STOPS RESPONDING
---------------------------

which contains the cursor, to occupy the full screen.  It deletes all
other windows.[K

[?25l* INSERTING AND DELETING

If you want to insert text, just type the text.  Ordinary characters,
like A, 7, *, etc., are inserted as you type them.  To insert a[K
Newline character, type <Return> (this is the key on the keyboard
which is sometimes labeled "Enter").
[K
To delete the character immediately before the current cursor
position, type <DEL>.  This is the key on the keyboard usually labeled
"Backspace"--the same one you normally use, outside Emacs, to delete
the last character typed.
[K
There may also be another key on your keyboard labeled <Delete>, but
that's not the one we refer to as <DEL>.[K

You've now learned the most basic way of typing something in[K
Emacs and correcting errors.  You can delete by words or lines

[K
        <DEL>        Delete the character just before the cursor[K

Notice that <DEL> and C-d vs M-<DEL> and M-d extend the parallel
started by C-f and M-f (well, <DEL> is not really a control character,
but let's not worry about that).  C-k and M-k are like C-e and M-e,
sort of, in that lines are paired with sentences.
[K
You can also kill a segment of text with one uniform method.  Move to
one end of that part, and type C-<SPC>.  (<SPC> is the Space bar.)
Next, move the cursor to the other end of the text you intend to kill.
As you do this, Emacs highlights the text between the cursor and the
position where you typed C-<SPC>.  Finally, type C-w.  This kills all
the text between the two positions.[K

The difference between "killing" and "deleting" is that "killed" text[K
can be reinserted (at any position), whereas "deleted" things cannot
be reinserted in this way (you can, however, undo a deletion--see below).
Reinsertion of killed text is called "yanking".  Generally, the
commands that can remove a lot of text kill the text (they are set up so
that you can yank the text), while the commands that remove just one
character, or only remove blank lines and spaces, do deletion (so you[K
cannot yank that text).  <DEL> and C-d do deletion in the simplest[K
case, with no argument.  When given an argument, they kill instead.[K
[K
>> Move the cursor to the beginning of a line which is not empty.
   Then type C-k to kill the text on that line.[K[23;30H[7m2% L363[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25l>> Move the cursor to the beginning of a line which is not empty.
   Then type C-k to kill the text on that line.[K[4;11Hk a second time.  You'll see that it kills the Newline[5;4Hwhich follows that line.[K
[K
Note that a single C-k kills the contents of the line, and a second
C-k kills the line itself, and makes all the other lines move up.  C-k
treats a numeric argument specially: it kills that many lines AND
their contents.  This is not mere repetition.  C-u 2 C-k kills two
lines and their newlines; typing C-k twice would not do that.[K
[K
Reinserting killed text is called "yanking".  (Think of it as yanking[K
back, or pulling back, some text that was taken away.)  You can yank
the killed text either at the same place where it was killed, or at[K
some other place in the text you are editing, or even in a different
file.  You can yank the same text several times; that makes multiple[K
[Copies of it.  Some other editors call killing and yanking "cutting"
and "pasting" (see the Glossary in the Emacs manual).[K

The command for yanking is C-y.  It reinserts the last killed text,
at the current cursor position.[K

M-y replaces that yanked text with the previous kill.  Typing M-y[K

[K
If you make a change to the text, and then decide that it was a[K
mistake, you can undo the change with the undo command, C-/.[K
[K
Normally, C-/ undoes the changes made by one command; if you repeat
C-/ several times in a row, each repetition undoes one more command.[K
[K
But there are two exceptions: commands that do not change the text
don't count (this includes cursor motion commands and scrolling
commands), and self-inserting characters are usually handled in groups
of up to 20.  (This is to reduce the number of C-/'s you have to type
to undo insertion of text.)[K

In order to make the text you edit permanent, you must put it in a
file.  Otherwise, it will go away when you exit Emacs.  In order to
put your text in a file, you must "find" the file before you enter the
text.  (This is also called "visiting" the file.)[K
[K
Finding a file means that you see the contents of the file within[K
Emacs.  In many ways, it is as if you were editing the file itself.
However, the changes you make using Emacs do not become permanent
until you "save" the file.  This is so you can avoid leaving a
half-changed file on the system when you do not want to.  Even when
you save, Emacs leaves the original file under a changed name in case
you later decide that your changes were a mistake.[K[23;30H[7m1% L471[0m[39;49m[27m[12;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m2[0m[39;49m[27m[13;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[14;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m4[0m[39;49m[27m[15;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m5[0m[39;49m[27m[16;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m6[0m[39;49m[27m[17;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m7[0m[39;49m[27m[18;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m8[0m[39;49m[27m[19;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m9[0m[39;49m[27m[20;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;35H[?25l[7m80[0m[39;49m[27m[21;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m1[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[1;22r[2;1H[11M[1;24r[12;1H[K

[1mNAME[0m[m
       [1mtset[0m, [1mreset[0m - terminal initialization[m

[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mtset[0m [[1m-IQVcqrsw[0m] [[1m-[0m] [[1m-e[0m [4mch[24m] [[1m-i[0m [4mch[24m] [[1m-k[0m [4mch[24m] [[1m-m[0m [4mmapping[24m] [[4mterminal[24m][m
       [1mreset[0m [[1m-IQVcqrsw[0m] [[1m-[0m] [[1m-e[0m [4mch[24m] [[1m-i[0m [4mch[24m] [[1m-k[0m [4mch[24m] [[1m-m[0m [4mmapping[24m] [[4mterminal[24m][m

[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mTset[0m initializes terminals.  [1mTset[0m first determines the type of terminal[m
       that you are using.  This determination is done as follows,  using  the[m
       first terminal type found.[m
[m
       1. The [1mterminal[0m argument specified on the command line.[m
[m
       2. The value of the [1mTERM[0m environmental variable.[m
[m
       3.  (BSD  systems only.) The terminal type associated with the standard[m
       error output device in the [4m/etc/ttys[24m file.   (On  System-V-like  UNIXes[m
       and  systems using that convention, [4mgetty[24m does this job by setting [1mTERM[0m[m
       according to the type passed to it by [4m/etc/inittab[24m.)[m
[m
[7m Manual page reset(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESC   ESC[K[ [[K6 6[K~ ~[K       4. The default terminal type, ``unknown''.[m
[m
       If the terminal type was not specified  on  the  command-line,  the  [1m-m[0m[m
       option mappings are then applied (see the section [1mTERMINAL[0m [1mTYPE[0m [1mMAPPING[0m[m
       for more information).  Then, if the terminal type begins with a  ques[m
       tion  mark (``?''), the user is prompted for confirmation of the termi[m
       nal type.  An empty response confirms the type, or, another type can be[m
       entered  to specify a new type.  Once the terminal type has been deter[m
       mined, the terminfo entry for the terminal is retrieved.   If  no  ter[m
       minfo  entry  is  found  for the type, the user is prompted for another[m
       terminal type.[m
[m
       Once the terminfo entry  is  retrieved,  the  window  size,  backspace,[m
       interrupt  and  line  kill characters (among many other things) are set[m
       and the terminal and tab initialization strings are sent to  the  stan[m
       dard  error  output.   Finally,  if  the erase, interrupt and line kill[m
       characters have changed, or are not set to their default values,  their[m
       values  are  displayed  to the standard error output.  Use the [1m-c[0m or [1m-w[0m[m
       option to select only the window sizing versus  the  other  initializa[m
       tion.  If neither option is given, both are assumed.[m
[m
       When  invoked  as  [1mreset[0m,  [1mtset[0m  sets  cooked and echo modes, turns off[m
       cbreak and raw modes, turns on newline translation and resets any unset[m
[7m Manual page reset(1) line 26 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESC   ESC[K[ [[K6 6[K~ ~[K       special  characters  to  their default values before doing the terminal[m
       initialization described above.  This is useful after  a  program  dies[m
       leaving a terminal in an abnormal state.  Note, you may have to type[m

           [1m<LF>reset<LF>[0m[m
[m
       (the  line-feed character is normally control-J) to get the terminal to[m
       work, as carriage-return may no longer  work  in  the  abnormal  state.[m
       Also, the terminal will often not echo the command.[m
[m
       The options are as follows:[m

       The arguments for the [1m-e[0m, [1m-i[0m, and [1m-k[0m options may either be  entered  as[m

[1mSETTING[0m [1mTHE[0m [1mENVIRONMENT[0m[m
       It is often desirable to enter the terminal type and information  about[m
       the terminal's capabilities into the shell's environment.  This is done[m
       using the [1m-s[0m option.[m
[m
       When the [1m-s[0m option is specified, the commands to enter the  information[m
       into  the  shell's  environment are written to the standard output.  If[m
       the [1mSHELL[0m environmental variable ends in ``csh'', the commands are  for[m
       [1mcsh[0m,  otherwise, they are for [1msh[0m.  Note, the [1mcsh[0m commands set and unset[m
       the shell variable [1mnoglob[0m, leaving it unset.  The following line in the[m
       [1m.login[0m or [1m.profile[0m files will initialize the environment correctly:[m
[m
           eval `tset -s options ... `[m
[m
[1mTERMINAL[0m [1mTYPE[0m [1mMAPPING[0m[m
       When the terminal is not hardwired into the system (or the current sys[m
       tem information is  incorrect)  the  terminal  type  derived  from  the[m
       [4m/etc/ttys[24m  file  or  the [1mTERM[0m environmental variable is often something[m
[7m Manual page reset(1) line 95 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESC   ESC[K[ [[K6 6[K~ ~[K       generic like [1mnetwork[0m, [1mdialup[0m, or [1munknown[0m.   When  [1mtset[0m  is  used  in  a[m
       startup  script  it is often desirable to provide information about the[m
       type of terminal used on such ports.[m
[m
       The purpose of the [1m-m[0m option is to map from some set of conditions to a[m
       terminal type, that is, to tell [1mtset[0m ``If I'm on this port at a partic[m
       ular speed, guess that I'm on that kind of terminal''.[m
[m
       The argument to the [1m-m[0m option consists of an  optional  port  type,  an[m
       optional  operator,  an  optional  baud rate specification, an optional[m
       colon (``:'') character and a terminal type.  The port type is a string[m
       (delimited  by either the operator or the colon character).  The opera[m
       tor may be any combination of ``>'', ``<'',  ``@'',  and  ``!'';  ``>''[m
       means  greater  than,  ``<''  means less than, ``@'' means equal to and[m
       ``!'' inverts the sense of the test.  The baud rate is specified  as  a[m
       number  and  is  compared  with  the speed of the standard error output[m
       (which should be the control terminal).  The terminal type is a string.[m
[m
       If the terminal type is not specified on the command line, the [1m-m[0m  map[m
       pings are applied to the terminal type.  If the port type and baud rate[m
       match the mapping, the terminal type specified in the mapping  replaces[m
       the  current  type.   If  more than one mapping is specified, the first[m
       applicable mapping is used.[m
[7m Manual page reset(1) line 118 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESC   ESC[K[ [[K6 6[K~ ~[K[m
       For example, consider the following  mapping:  [1mdialup>9600:vt100[0m.   The[m
       port type is dialup , the operator is >, the baud rate specification is[m
       9600, and the terminal type is vt100.  The result of this mapping is to[m
       specify  that  if  the  terminal  type  is [1mdialup[0m, and the baud rate is[m
       greater than 9600 baud, a terminal type of [1mvt100[0m will be used.[m
[m
       If no baud rate is specified, the terminal type  will  match  any  baud[m
       rate.   If  no port type is specified, the terminal type will match any[m
       port type.  For example, [1m-m[0m [1mdialup:vt100[0m  [1m-m[0m  [1m:?xterm[0m  will  cause  any[m
       dialup port, regardless of baud rate, to match the terminal type vt100,[m
       and any non-dialup port type to match the terminal type ?xterm.   Note,[m
       because  of  the  leading  question mark, the user will be queried on a[m
       default port as to whether they are actually using an xterm terminal.[m
[m
       No whitespace characters are  permitted  in  the  [1m-m[0m  option  argument.[m
       Also,  to avoid problems with meta-characters, it is suggested that the[m
       entire [1m-m[0m option argument be placed within single quote characters, and[m
       that [1mcsh[0m users insert a backslash character (``\'') before any exclama[m
       tion marks (``!'').[m

[1mHISTORY[0m[m
       The [1mtset[0m command appeared in BSD 3.0.  The [1mncurses[0m  implementation  was[m

[1mCOMPATIBILITY[0m[m
       The [1mtset[0m utility has been provided for backward-compatibility with  BSD[m
       environments  (under  most modern UNIXes, [1m/etc/inittab[0m and [4mgetty[24m(1) can[m
       set [1mTERM[0m appropriately for each dial-up line; this  obviates  what  was[m
       [1mtset[0m's  most  important  use).  This implementation behaves like 4.4BSD[m
       tset, with a few exceptions specified here.[m
[m
       The [1m-S[0m option of BSD tset no longer works; it prints an  error  message[m
       to  stderr  and dies.  The [1m-s[0m option only sets [1mTERM[0m, not [1mTERMCAP[0m.  Both[m
       these changes are because the [1mTERMCAP[0m variable is no  longer  supported[m
       under  terminfo-based  [1mncurses[0m, which makes [1mtset[0m [1m-S[0m useless (we made it[m
       die noisily rather than silently induce lossage).[m
[m
       There was an undocumented 4.4BSD feature that invoking tset via a  link[m
       named  `TSET`  (or via any other name beginning with an upper-case let[m
       ter) set the terminal to use upper-case only.  This  feature  has  been[m
       omitted.[m
[m
       The [1m-A[0m, [1m-E[0m, [1m-h[0m, [1m-u[0m and [1m-v[0m options were deleted from the [1mtset[0m utility in[m
       4.4BSD.  None of them were documented in 4.3BSD and all are of  limited[m
[7m Manual page reset(1) line 164 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESC   ESC[K[ [[K6 6[K~ ~[K       utility  at  best.   The [1m-a[0m, [1m-d[0m, and [1m-p[0m options are similarly not docu[m
       mented or useful, but were retained as they appear to be in  widespread[m
       use.   It is strongly recommended that any usage of these three options[m
       be changed to use the [1m-m[0m option instead.  The [1m-n[0m  option  remains,  but[m
       has  no effect.  The [1m-adnp[0m options are therefore omitted from the usage[m
       summary above.[m
[m
       It is still permissible to specify the [1m-e[0m, [1m-i[0m, and [1m-k[0m  options  without[m
       arguments, although it is strongly recommended that such usage be fixed[m
       to explicitly specify the character.[m
[m
       As of 4.4BSD, executing [1mtset[0m as [1mreset[0m no longer implies the [1m-Q[0m  option.[m
       Also, the interaction between the - option and the [4mterminal[24m argument in[m
       some historic implementations of [1mtset[0m has been removed.[m

put your text in a file, you must "find" the file before you enter the[K

[K
Finding a file means that you see the contents of the file within[K
Emacs.  In many ways, it is as if you were editing the file itself.[K
However, the changes you make using Emacs do not become permanent[K
until you "save" the file.  This is so you can avoid leaving a[K
half-changed file on the system when you do not want to.  Even when[K
you save, Emacs leaves the original file under a changed name in case[K
you later decide that your changes were a mistake.[K
[K

like that.  This part of the screen normally shows the name of the[K
file that you are visiting.  Right now, you are visiting your personal[K
copy of the Emacs tutorial, which is called "TUTORIAL".  When you find[K
a file with Emacs, that file's name will appear in that precise spot.[K

have to say what file name you want.  We say the command "reads an[K
argument" (in this case, the argument is the name of the file).  After[K

When you have several buffers, only one of them is "current" at any
time.  That buffer is the one you edit.  If you want to edit another
buffer, you need to "switch" to it.  If you want to switch to a buffer
that corresponds to a file, you can do it by visiting the file again
with C-x C-f.  But there is an easier way: use the C-x b command.
In that command, you have to type the buffer's name.

* EXTENDING THE COMMAND SET[K
---------------------------
[K
There are many, many more Emacs commands than could possibly be put
on all the control and meta characters.  Emacs gets around this with
the X (eXtend) command.  This comes in two flavors:
[K[19;4H     C-x     Character eXtend.  Followed by one character.[K[20;4H     M-x     Named command eXtend.  Followed by a long name.

There are many, many more Emacs commands than could possibly be put
on all the control and meta characters.  Emacs gets around this with
the X (eXtend) command.  This comes in two flavors:
[K[8;4H     C-x     Character eXtend.  Followed by one character.[K[9;4H     M-x     Named command eXtend.  Followed by a long name.

These are commands that are generally useful but are used less than the
commands you have already learned about.  You have already seen a few
of them: the file commands C-x C-f to Find and C-x C-s to Save, for
example.  Another example is the command to end the Emacs
session--this is the command C-x C-c.  (Do not worry about losing[K
changes you have made; C-x C-c offers to save each changed file before
it kills Emacs.)[K

If you are using a graphical display, you don't need any special
command to move from Emacs to another application.  You can do this
with the mouse or with window manager commands.  However, if you're
using a text terminal which can only show one application at a time,[K[23;30H[7m5% L617[0m[39;49m[27m[12;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m8[0m[39;49m[27m[13;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m9[0m[39;49m[27m[14;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;35H[?25l[7m20[0m[39;49m[27m[15;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m1[0m[39;49m[27m[16;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m2[0m[39;49m[27m[17;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[18;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m4[0m[39;49m[27m[19;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m5[0m[39;49m[27m[20;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m6[0m[39;49m[27m[21;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m7[0m[39;49m[27m[22;3H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[1;22r[2;1H[11M[1;24r[12;1H[?25lyou need to "suspend" Emacs to move to any other application.[K
[K
C-z is the command to exit Emacs *temporarily*--so that you can go[K
back to the same Emacs session afterward.  When Emacs is running on a[K
text terminal, C-z "suspends" Emacs; that is, it returns to the shell[K
but does not destroy the Emacs job.  In the most common shells, you[K
can resume Emacs with the `fg' command or with `%emacs'.[K
[K
The time to use C-x C-c is when you are about to log out.  It's also[K
the right thing to use to exit an Emacs invoked for a quick edit, such[K
as by a mail handling utility.[K

Named eXtended commands are commands which are used even less[K
frequently, or commands which are used only in certain modes.  An
example is the command replace-string, which replaces one string with
another in the buffer.  When you type M-x, Emacs prompts you at the
bottom of the screen with M-x and you should type the name of the
command; in this case, "replace-string".  Just type "repl s<TAB>" and
Emacs will complete the name.  (<TAB> is the Tab key, usually found
above the CapsLock or Shift key near the left edge of the keyboard.)
Submit the command name with <Return>.[K

* AUTO SAVE[K
-----------[K

When you have made changes in a file, but you have not saved them yet,
they could be lost if your computer crashes.  To protect you from
this, Emacs periodically writes an "auto save" file for each file that
you are editing.  The auto save file name has a # at the beginning and
the end; for example, if your file is named "hello.c", its auto save
file's name is "#hello.c#".  When you save the file in the normal way,
Emacs deletes its auto save file.

-----------[K
[K
If Emacs sees that you are typing multicharacter commands slowly, it
shows them to you at the bottom of the screen in an area called the
"echo area".  The echo area contains the bottom line of the screen.
[K

-----------

The line immediately above the echo area is called the "mode line".
The mode line says something like this:

 -:**-  TUTORIAL       63% L749    (Fundamental)[K
[K
This line gives useful information about the status of Emacs and[K
the text you are editing.

You already know what the filename means--it is the file you have
found.  NN% indicates your current position in the buffer text; it
means that NN percent of the buffer is above the top of the screen.
If the top of the buffer is on the screen, it will say "Top" instead
of " 0%".  If the bottom of the buffer is on the screen, it will say
"Bot". [?25l* SEARCHING[K
-----------[K
[K
Emacs can do searches for strings (a "string" is a group of contiguous
characters) either forward through the text or backward through it.[K
Searching for a string is a cursor motion command; it moves the cursor
to the next place where that string appears.[K

The Emacs search command is "incremental".  This means that the
search happens while you type in the string to search for.

The command to initiate a search is C-s for forward search, and C-r
for reverse search.  BUT WAIT!  Don't try them now.

When you type C-s you'll notice that the string "I-search" appears as[K
a prompt in the echo area.  This tells you that Emacs is in what is
called an incremental search waiting for you to type the thing that[K
you want to search for.  <Return> terminates a search.

[?25lIf you are in the middle of an incremental search and type <DEL>, the[K
search "retreats" to an earlier location.  If you type <DEL> just[K
after you had typed C-s to advance to the next occurrence of a search[K
string, the <DEL> moves the cursor back to an earlier occurrence.  If[K
there are no earlier occurrences, the <DEL> erases the last character[K
in the search string.  For instance, suppose you have typed "c", to[K
search for the first occurrence of "c".  Now if you type "u", the[K
cursor will move to the first occurrence of "cu".  Now type <DEL>.[K
This erases the "u" from the search string, and the cursor moves back[K
to the first occurrence of "c".[K

[?25lIf you are in the middle of a search and type a control or meta[K
character (with a few exceptions--characters that are special in a[K
search, such as C-s and C-r), the search is terminated.[K
[K
C-s starts a search that looks for any occurrence of the search string[K
AFTER the current cursor position.  If you want to search for[K
something earlier in the text, type C-r instead.  Everything that we[K
have said about C-s also applies to C-r, except that the direction of[K
the search is reversed.[K

* MULTIPLE FRAMES
------------------[K

Emacs can also create multiple "frames".  A frame is what we call one
collection of windows, together with its menus, scroll bars, echo[K
area, etc.  On graphical displays, what Emacs calls a "frame" is what
most other applications call a "window".  Multiple graphical frames
can be shown on the screen at the same time.  On a text terminal, only
one frame can be shown at a time.

[?25l* MULTIPLE FRAMES
------------------[K

Emacs can also create multiple "frames".  A frame is what we call one
collection of windows, together with its menus, scroll bars, echo[K
area, etc.  On graphical displays, what Emacs calls a "frame" is what
most other applications call a "window".  Multiple graphical frames
can be shown on the screen at the same time.  On a text terminal, only
one frame can be shown at a time.

>> Type M-x make-frame <Return>.

You can do everything you did in the original frame in the new frame.
There is nothing special about the first frame.[K
[K
>> Type M-x delete-frame <Return>.[K
   This removes the selected frame.[K
[K

* RECURSIVE EDITING LEVELS[K
--------------------------
[K
Sometimes you will get into what is called a "recursive editing
level".  This is indicated by square brackets in the mode line,
surrounding the parentheses around the major mode name. example, you might see [(Fundamental)] instead of (Fundamental).[K

eliminating extra windows, and getting out of the minibuffer.

[?25l* GETTING MORE HELP[K
-------------------[K

In this tutorial we have tried to supply just enough information to[K
get you started using Emacs.  There is so much available in Emacs that
it would be impossible to explain it all here.  However, you may want
to learn more about Emacs since it has many other useful features.[K
Emacs provides commands for reading documentation about Emacs[K
commands.  These "help" commands all start with the character
CONTROL-h, which is called "the Help character".

To use the Help features, type the C-h character, and then a
character saying what kind of help you want.  If you are REALLY lost,
type C-h ? and Emacs will tell you what kinds of help it can give.
[Cf you have typed C-h and decide you do not want any help, just[K
type C-g to cancel it.[K
[K
(If C-h does not display a message about help at the bottom of the
screen, try typing the F1 key or M-x help <Return> instead.)[K[23;30H[7m8% L980[0m[39;49m[27m[12;62H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m1[0m[39;49m[27m[13;49H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m2[0m[39;49m[27m[14;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;36H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[15;61H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[H
[?25l(If C-h does not display a message about help at the bottom of the
screen, try typing the F1 key or M-x help <Return> instead.)
[K
The most basic HELP feature is C-h c.  Type C-h, the character c, and
a command character or sequence; then Emacs displays a very brief
description of the command.[K
[K
>> Type C-h c C-p.[K
[K
The message should be something like this:[K
[K
        C-p runs the command previous-line[K

[Chis tells you the "name of the function".  Since function names
are chosen to indicate what the command does, they can serve as[K
very brief documentation--sufficient to remind you of commands you
have already learned.[K
[K
Multi-character commands such as C-x C-s and (if you have no META or
EDIT or ALT key) <ESC>v are also allowed after C-h c.[K
[K[23;29H[7m90% L989[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lEDIT or ALT key) <ESC>v are also allowed after C-h c.[K
[K
To get more information about a command, use C-h k instead of C-h c.
[K
>> Type C-h k C-p.[K
[K
This displays the documentation of the function, as well as its name,
in an Emacs window.  When you are finished reading the output, type
C-x 1 to get rid of that window.  You do not have to do this right
away.  You can do some editing while referring to the help text, and
then type C-x 1.
[K
Here are some other useful C-h options:
[K
   C-h f        Describe a function.  You type in the name of the
                function.[K
[K
>> Try typing C-h f previous-line <Return>.
   This displays all the information Emacs has about the[K
   function which implements the C-p command.[K[23;30H[7m1% L1008[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25l   function which implements the C-p command.[K

A similar command C-h v displays the documentation of variables,[K
including those whose values you can set to customize Emacs behavior.
You need to type in the name of the variable when Emacs prompts for it.

   C-h a        Command Apropos.  Type in a keyword and Emacs will list
                all the commands whose names contain that keyword.[K
                These commands can all be invoked with META-x.[K
                For some commands, Command Apropos will also list a one
                or two character sequence which runs the same command.

>> Type C-h a file <Return>.[K

This displays in another window a list of all M-x commands with "file"
in their names.  You will see character-commands listed beside the
corresponding command names (such as C-x C-f beside find-file).
[K
>> Type C-M-v to scroll the help window.  Do this a few times.
[K
>> Type C-x 1 to delete the help window.[23;30H[7m2% L1027[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[K
[?25l>> Type C-x 1 to delete the help window.
[K
   C-h i        Read included Manuals (a.k.a. Info).  This command puts
                you into a special buffer called `*info*' where you[K
		can read manuals for the packages installed on your system.[8;4H             Type m emacs <Return> to read the Emacs manual.[K
		If you have never before used Info, type ? and Emacs
		will take you on a guided tour of Info mode facilities.
		Once you are through with this tutorial, you should[K
		consult the Emacs Info manual as your primary documentation.

* MORE FEATURES
---------------[K
[K
You can learn more about Emacs by reading its manual, either as a
printed book, or inside Emacs (use the Help menu or type C-h r).
Two features that you may like especially are completion, which saves
typing, and dired, which simplifies file handling.
[K[23;30H[7m4% L1046[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25ltyping, and dired, which simplifies file handling.
[K
Completion is a way to avoid unnecessary typing.  For instance, if you
want to switch to the *Messages* buffer, you can type C-x b *M<Tab>[K
and Emacs will fill in the rest of the buffer name as far as it can
determine from what you have already typed.  Completion also works for[K
command names and file names.  Completion is described in the Emacs
manual in the node called "Completion".[K
[K
Dired enables you to list files in a directory (and optionally its[K
subdirectories), move around that list, visit, rename, delete and[K
otherwise operate on the files.  Dired is described in the Emacs
manual in the node called "Dired".
[K
The manual also describes many other Emacs features.

[K
* CONCLUSION[K
------------[K
[K
To exit Emacs use C-x C-c.[23;30H[7m6% L1065[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[K
[?25lTo exit Emacs use C-x C-c.
[K
This tutorial is meant to be understandable to all new users, so if
you found something unclear, don't sit and blame yourself - complain!
[K

[K

[K

can be shown on the screen at the same time.  On a text terminal, only

[K
>> Type M-x make-frame <Return>.[K
   See a new frame appear on your screen.[K
[K
You can do everything you did in the original frame in the new frame.

* RECURSIVE EDITING LEVELS[23;30H[7m5% L952[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25lYou do not have to display the same buffer in both windows.  If you[K
use C-x C-f to find a file in one window, the other window does not
[Change.  You can find a file in each window independently.[K
[K
Here is another way to use two windows to display two different things:
[K
>> Type C-x 4 C-f followed by the name of one of your files.[9;4HEnd with <Return>.  See the specified file appear in the bottom
   window.  The cursor goes there, too.[K
[K
>> Type C-x o to go back to the top window, and C-x 1 to delete
   the bottom window.[K
[K

* MULTIPLE FRAMES[K
------------------[K
[K
Emacs can also create multiple "frames".  A frame is what we call one
collection of windows, together with its menus, scroll bars, echo
area, etc.  On graphical displays, what Emacs calls a "frame" is what
most other applications call a "window".  Multiple graphical frames[23;30H[7m3% L933[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25lC-M-v.[K
[K
C-M-v is an example of a CONTROL-META character.  If you have a META
(or Alt) key, you can type C-M-v by holding down both CONTROL and META
while typing v.  It does not matter whether CONTROL or META "comes[K
first," as both of these keys act by modifying the characters you
type.[K
[K
If you do not have a META key, and you use <ESC> instead, the order
does matter: you must type <ESC> followed by CONTROL-v, because
CONTROL-<ESC> v will not work.  This is because <ESC> is a character
in its own right, not a modifier key.

>> Type C-x 1 (in the top window) to get rid of the bottom window.
[K
(If you had typed C-x 1 in the bottom window, that would get rid
of the top one.  Think of this command as "Keep just one
window--the window I am already in.")[K
[K
You do not have to display the same buffer in both windows.  If you[K
use C-x C-f to find a file in one window, the other window does not[23;30H[7m2% L914[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25l>> Type C-M-v to scroll the bottom window.[3;4H(If you do not have a real META key, type <ESC> C-v.)
[K
>> Type C-x o ("o" for "other") to move the cursor to the bottom window.
>> Use C-v and M-v in the bottom window to scroll it.[K
   Keep reading these directions in the top window.[K
[K
>> Type C-x o again to move the cursor back to the top window.
   The cursor in the top window is just where it was before.[K
[K
You can keep using C-x o to switch between the windows.  The "selected
window", where most editing takes place, is the one with a prominent
cursor which blinks when you are not typing.  The other windows have
their own cursor positions; if you are running Emacs in a graphical
display, those cursors are drawn as unblinking hollow boxes.
[K
The command C-M-v is very useful when you are editing text in one[19;7H and using the other window just for reference.  Without leaving
the selected window, you can scroll the text in the other window with

there are no earlier occurrences, the <DEL> erases the last character
in the search string.  For instance, suppose you have typed "c", to

cursor will move to the first occurrence of "cu".  Now type <DEL>.[K
This erases the "u" from the search string, and the cursor moves back
to the first occurrence of "c".[K

character (with a few exceptions--characters that are special in a
search, such as C-s and C-r), the search is terminated.

Emacs can do searches for strings (a "string" is a group of contiguous

Searching for a string is a cursor motion command; it moves the cursor
to the next place where that string appears.

The Emacs search command is "incremental".  This means that the[K
search happens while you type in the string to search for.[K
[K
The command to initiate a search is C-s for forward search, and C-r[K
for reverse search.  BUT WAIT!  Don't try them now.

breaks the line in between words automatically whenever you insert

* AUTO SAVE
-----------
[K
When you have made changes in a file, but you have not saved them yet,
they could be lost if your computer crashes.  To protect you from[K
this, Emacs periodically writes an "auto save" file for each file that
you are editing.  The auto save file name has a # at the beginning and
the end; for example, if your file is named "hello.c", its auto save
file's name is "#hello.c#".  When you save the file in the normal way,
Emacs deletes its auto save file.
[K
If the computer crashes, you can recover your auto-saved editing by
finding the file normally (the file you were editing, not the auto
save file) and then typing M-x recover-file <Return>.  When it asks for[23;30H[7m0% L686[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2;4H[?25l     C-x C-c         Quit Emacs[K
	C-x 1           Delete all but one window[4;4H     C-x u           Undo[K
[K
Named eXtended commands are commands which are used even less
frequently, or commands which are used only in certain modes.  An
example is the command replace-string, which replaces one string with
another in the buffer.  When you type M-x, Emacs prompts you at the
bottom of the screen with M-x and you should type the name of the
command; in this case, "replace-string".  Just type "repl s<TAB>" and
Emacs will complete the name.  (<TAB> is the Tab key, usually found[K
above the CapsLock or Shift key near the left edge of the keyboard.)
Submit the command name with <Return>.[K
[K
The replace-string command requires two arguments--the string to be[K
replaced, and the string to replace it with.  You must end each[K
argument with <Return>.[K

C-z is the command to exit Emacs *temporarily*--so that you can go
back to the same Emacs session afterward.  When Emacs is running on a
text terminal, C-z "suspends" Emacs; that is, it returns to the shell
but does not destroy the Emacs job.  In the most common shells, you
can resume Emacs with the `fg' command or with `%emacs'.[K
[K
The time to use C-x C-c is when you are about to log out.  It's also
the right thing to use to exit an Emacs invoked for a quick edit, such
as by a mail handling utility.[K
[K
There are many C-x commands.  Here is a list of the ones you have learned:

        C-x C-f         Find file[K
        C-x C-s         Save file[K
        C-x s           Save some buffers
	C-x C-b         List buffers
        C-x b           Switch buffer[K[21;4H     C-x C-c         Quit Emacs[K
	C-x 1           Delete all but one window[23;30H[7m7% L648[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25lThere are many, many more Emacs commands than could possibly be put

the X (eXtend) command.  This comes in two flavors:[K
[K
        C-x     Character eXtend.  Followed by one character.[K
        M-x     Named command eXtend.  Followed by a long name.[K
[K
These are commands that are generally useful but are used less than the
commands you have already learned about.  You have already seen a few
of them: the file commands C-x C-f to Find and C-x C-s to Save, for[K
example.  Another example is the command to end the Emacs
session--this is the command C-x C-c.  (Do not worry about losing
changes you have made; C-x C-c offers to save each changed file before[K
it kills Emacs.)
[K
If you are using a graphical display, you don't need any special

with the mouse or with window manager commands.  However, if you're
using a text terminal which can only show one application at a time,
you need to "suspend" Emacs to move to any other application.

* FILES[K
-------[K
[K
In order to make the text you edit permanent, you must put it in a
file.  Otherwise, it will go away when you exit Emacs.  In order to
put your text in a file, you must "find" the file before you enter the
text.  (This is also called "visiting" the file.)[K
[K
Finding a file means that you see the contents of the file within
Emacs.  In many ways, it is as if you were editing the file itself.
However, the changes you make using Emacs do not become permanent[23;30H[7m1% L477[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25l* UNDO[K
------[K

If you make a change to the text, and then decide that it was a[K
mistake, you can undo the change with the undo command, C-/.
[K
Normally, C-/ undoes the changes made by one command; if you repeat
C-/ several times in a row, each repetition undoes one more command.

But there are two exceptions: commands that do not change the text
don't count (this includes cursor motion commands and scrolling
commands), and self-inserting characters are usually handled in groups
of up to 20.  (This is to reduce the number of C-/'s you have to type
to undo insertion of text.)[K
[K
>> Kill this line with C-k, then type C-/ and it should reappear.[K
[K
C-_ is an alternative undo command; it works exactly the same as C-/.
On some text terminals, typing C-/ actually sends C-_ to Emacs.[K
Alternatively, C-x u also works exactly like C-/, but is a little less
convenient to type.[K[23;29H[7m39% L458[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25lcommand.  After you have done C-y to get the most recent kill, typing
M-y replaces that yanked text with the previous kill.  Typing M-y
again and again brings in earlier and earlier kills.  When you have
reached the text you are looking for, you do not have to do anything to
keep it.  Just go on with your editing, leaving the yanked text where
it is.
[K
If you M-y enough times, you come back to the starting point (the most
recent kill).
[K

   Do more M-y's and see what you get.  Keep doing them until[16;4Hthe second kill line comes back, and then a few more.
   If you like, you can try giving M-y positive and negative[K[18;4Harguments.

Note that a single C-k kills the contents of the line, and a second
C-k kills the line itself, and makes all the other lines move up.  C-k
treats a numeric argument specially: it kills that many lines AND
their contents.  This is not mere repetition.  C-u 2 C-k kills two
lines and their newlines; typing C-k twice would not do that.
[K
Reinserting killed text is called "yanking".  (Think of it as yanking
back, or pulling back, some text that was taken away.)  You can yank
the killed text either at the same place where it was killed, or at
some other place in the text you are editing, or even in a different
file.  You can yank the same text several times; that makes multiple
copies of it.  Some other editors call killing and yanking "cutting"
and "pasting" (see the Glossary in the Emacs manual).[K
[K
The command for yanking is C-y.  It reinserts the last killed text,[23;30H[7m4% L401[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25lthe text between the two positions.

The difference between "killing" and "deleting" is that "killed" text
can be reinserted (at any position), whereas "deleted" things cannot
be reinserted in this way (you can, however, undo a deletion--see below).
Reinsertion of killed text is called "yanking".  Generally, the[K
commands that can remove a lot of text kill the text (they are set up so
that you can yank the text), while the commands that remove just one
character, or only remove blank lines and spaces, do deletion (so you
[Cannot yank that text).  <DEL> and C-d do deletion in the simplest[K
case, with no argument.  When given an argument, they kill instead.

[?25l* INSERTING AND DELETING[K
------------------------
[K
If you want to insert text, just type the text.  Ordinary characters,
like A, 7, *, etc., are inserted as you type them.  To insert a[K
Newline character, type <Return> (this is the key on the keyboard[K[10;3Hich is sometimes labeled "Enter").[K
[K
To delete the character immediately before the current cursor
position, type <DEL>.  This is the key on the keyboard usually labeled
"Backspace"--the same one you normally use, outside Emacs, to delete[K
the last character typed.[K

There may also be another key on your keyboard labeled <Delete>, but
that's not the one we refer to as <DEL>.[K

one-window editing.  It is simple:

other windows.[K

* BASIC CURSOR CONTROL[K
----------------------[K
[K
Moving from screenful to screenful is useful, but how do you
move to a specific place within the text on the screen?[K
[K
There are several ways you can do this.  You can use the arrow keys,
but it's more efficient to keep your hands in the standard position
and use the commands C-p, C-b, C-f, and C-n.  These characters[23;30H[7m4% L66[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[2d[?25lThe first thing that you need to know is how to move around from place

[?25l* INSERTING AND DELETING
------------------------[K

If you want to insert text, just type the text.  Ordinary characters,
like A, 7, *, etc., are inserted as you type them.  To insert a[K
Newline character, type <Return> (this is the key on the keyboard
which is sometimes labeled "Enter").
[K
To delete the character immediately before the current cursor
position, type <DEL>.  This is the key on the keyboard usually labeled
"Backspace"--the same one you normally use, outside Emacs, to delete
the last character typed.
[K
There may also be another key on your keyboard labeled <Delete>, but
that's not the one we refer to as <DEL>.[K
[K

graphical display, little curved arrows appear in the narrow spaces on
each side of the text area (the left and right "fringes"), to indicate[10;3Here a line has been continued.  If you're using a text terminal, the
continued line is indicated by a backslash ("\") on the rightmost
screen column.[K

You can also kill a segment of text with one uniform method.  Move to
one end of that part, and type C-<SPC>.  (<SPC> is the Space bar.)
Next, move the cursor to the other end of the text you intend to kill.
As you do this, Emacs highlights the text between the cursor and the
position where you typed C-<SPC>.  Finally, type C-w.  This kills all
the text between the two positions.[K

The difference between "killing" and "deleting" is that "killed" text[K
can be reinserted (at any position), whereas "deleted" things cannot
be reinserted in this way (you can, however, undo a deletion--see below).
Reinsertion of killed text is called "yanking".  Generally, the
commands that can remove a lot of text kill the text (they are set up so
that you can yank the text), while the commands that remove just one
character, or only remove blank lines and spaces, do deletion (so you[K
cannot yank that text).  <DEL> and C-d do deletion in the simplest[K
case, with no argument.  When given an argument, they kill instead.[K
[K
>> Move the cursor to the beginning of a line which is not empty.[23;30H[7m2% L362[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[K

   Then type C-k to kill the text on that line.[K[5;11Hk a second time.  You'll see that it kills the Newline[6;4Hwhich follows that line.[K
[K
Note that a single C-k kills the contents of the line, and a second
C-k kills the line itself, and makes all the other lines move up.  C-k
treats a numeric argument specially: it kills that many lines AND
their contents.  This is not mere repetition.  C-u 2 C-k kills two
lines and their newlines; typing C-k twice would not do that.[K
[K
Reinserting killed text is called "yanking".  (Think of it as yanking[K
back, or pulling back, some text that was taken away.)  You can yank
the killed text either at the same place where it was killed, or at[K
some other place in the text you are editing, or even in a different
file.  You can yank the same text several times; that makes multiple[K
[Copies of it.  Some other editors call killing and yanking "cutting"
and "pasting" (see the Glossary in the Emacs manual).[K

The command for yanking is C-y.  It reinserts the last killed text,[23;30H[7m4% L381[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h
[?25lThe command for yanking is C-y.  It reinserts the last killed text,
at the current cursor position.[K

If you do several C-k's in a row, all of the killed text is saved[K
together, so that one C-y will yank all of the lines at once.[K

command.  After you have done C-y to get the most recent kill, typing
M-y replaces that yanked text with the previous kill.  Typing M-y[K[23;30H[7m6% L400[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lcommand.  After you have done C-y to get the most recent kill, typing

[Cgain and again brings in earlier and earlier kills.  When you have

If you M-y enough times, you come back to the starting point (the most

* UNDO[K
------[K[23;30H[7m7% L419[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25l* UNDO[K
------[K
[K
If you make a change to the text, and then decide that it was a[K
mistake, you can undo the change with the undo command, C-/.[K
[K
Normally, C-/ undoes the changes made by one command; if you repeat
C-/ several times in a row, each repetition undoes one more command.[K
[K
But there are two exceptions: commands that do not change the text
don't count (this includes cursor motion commands and scrolling
commands), and self-inserting characters are usually handled in groups
of up to 20.  (This is to reduce the number of C-/'s you have to type
to undo insertion of text.)[K
[K
>> Kill this line with C-k, then type C-/ and it should reappear.
[K
C-_ is an alternative undo command; it works exactly the same as C-/.
On some text terminals, typing C-/ actually sends C-_ to Emacs.
Alternatively, C-x u also works exactly like C-/, but is a little less
convenient to type.[23;30H[7m9% L438[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lAlternatively, C-x u also works exactly like C-/, but is a little less
convenient to type.

A numeric argument to C-/, C-_, or C-x u acts as a repeat count.
[K
You can undo deletion of text just as you can undo killing of text.
The distinction between killing something and deleting it affects[K
whether you can yank it with C-y; it makes no difference for undo.[K

[K
* FILES[K
-------[K
[K
In order to make the text you edit permanent, you must put it in a
file.  Otherwise, it will go away when you exit Emacs.  In order to
put your text in a file, you must "find" the file before you enter the
text.  (This is also called "visiting" the file.)
[K
Finding a file means that you see the contents of the file within
Emacs.  In many ways, it is as if you were editing the file itself.[K
However, the changes you make using Emacs do not become permanent[23;29H[7m41% L457[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lEmacs.  In many ways, it is as if you were editing the file itself.[K
However, the changes you make using Emacs do not become permanent
until you "save" the file.  This is so you can avoid leaving a
half-changed file on the system when you do not want to.  Even when
you save, Emacs leaves the original file under a changed name in case
you later decide that your changes were a mistake.[K
[K
If you look near the bottom of the screen you will see a line that
begins with dashes, and starts with " -:---  TUTORIAL" or something
like that.  This part of the screen normally shows the name of the
file that you are visiting.  Right now, you are visiting your personal
copy of the Emacs tutorial, which is called "TUTORIAL".  When you find
a file with Emacs, that file's name will appear in that precise spot.
[K
One special thing about the command for finding a file is that you[K
have to say what file name you want.  We say the command "reads an[K
argument" (in this case, the argument is the name of the file).  After
you type the command
[K
        C-x C-f   Find a file[K
[K[23;30H[7m2% L476[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25l        C-x C-f   Find a file[K
[K
Emacs asks you to type the file name.  The file name you type appears
on the bottom line of the screen.  The bottom line is called the[K
minibuffer when it is used for this sort of input.  You can use[K
ordinary Emacs editing commands to edit the file name.

While you are entering the file name (or any minibuffer input),[K
you can cancel the command with C-g.[K
[K
>> Type C-x C-f, then type C-g.  This cancels the minibuffer,[K
   and also cancels the C-x C-f command that was using the[K
   minibuffer.  So you do not find any file.[K

When you have finished entering the file name, type <Return> to[K
terminate it.  The minibuffer disappears, and the C-x C-f command goes
to work to find the file you chose.[K
[K
The file contents now appear on the screen, and you can edit the
contents.  When you wish to make your changes permanent, type the
command[23;30H[7m4% L495[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lcontents.  When you wish to make your changes permanent, type the
command
[K
        C-x C-s   Save the file[K
[K
This copies the text within Emacs into the file.  The first time you
do this, Emacs renames the original file to a new name so that it is
not lost.  The new name is made by adding "~" to the end of the
original file's name.  When saving is finished, Emacs displays the
name of the file written.
[K
>> Type C-x C-s TUTORIAL <Return>.[K[14;4HThis should save this tutorial to a file named TUTORIAL, and show[15;4H"Wrote ...TUTORIAL" at the bottom of the screen.
[K
You can find an existing file, to view it or edit it.  You can also[K
find a file which does not already exist.  This is the way to create a
file with Emacs: find the file, which starts out empty, and then begin
inserting the text for the file.  When you ask to "save" the file,
Emacs actually creates the file with the text that you have inserted.
From then on, you can consider yourself to be editing an already[23;30H[7m6% L514[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lEmacs actually creates the file with the text that you have inserted.
From then on, you can consider yourself to be editing an already
existing file.
[K

* BUFFERS[K
---------[K
[K
If you find a second file with C-x C-f, the first file remains[K
inside Emacs.  You can switch back to it by finding it again with
C-x C-f.  This way you can get quite a number of files inside Emacs.
[K
Emacs stores each file's text inside an object called a "buffer".[K
Finding a file makes a new buffer inside Emacs.  To see a list of the
buffers that currently exist, type
[K
        C-x C-b   List buffers[K
[K
>> Try C-x C-b now.[K
[K
See how each buffer has a name, and it may also have a file name for[23;30H[7m8% L533[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[K
[?25lSee how each buffer has a name, and it may also have a file name for
the file whose contents it holds.  ANY text you see in an Emacs window
is always part of some buffer.

>> Type C-x 1 to get rid of the buffer list.
[K
When you have several buffers, only one of them is "current" at any
time.  That buffer is the one you edit.  If you want to edit another
buffer, you need to "switch" to it.  If you want to switch to a buffer
that corresponds to a file, you can do it by visiting the file again
with C-x C-f.  But there is an easier way: use the C-x b command.
In that command, you have to type the buffer's name.[K
[K
>> Create a file named "foo" by typing C-x C-f foo <Return>.[17;4HThen type C-x b TUTORIAL <Return> to come back to this tutorial.
[K
Most of the time, the buffer's name is the same as the file name
(without the file directory part).  However, this is not always true.
The buffer list you make with C-x C-b shows you both the buffer name
and the file name of every buffer.[K
     [7m9% L552[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lThe buffer list you make with C-x C-b shows you both the buffer name
and the file name of every buffer.[K
[K
Some buffers do not correspond to files.  The buffer named
"*Buffer List*", which contains the buffer list that you made with
C-x C-b, does not have any file.  This TUTORIAL buffer initially did
not have a file, but now it does, because in the previous section you
typed C-x C-s and saved it to a file.[K
[K
The buffer named "*Messages*" also does not correspond to any file.[K
This buffer contains the messages that have appeared on the bottom[K
line during your Emacs session.[K
[K
>> Type C-x b *Messages* <Return> to look at the buffer of messages.
   Then type C-x b TUTORIAL <Return> to come back to this tutorial.
[K
If you make changes to the text of one file, then find another file,
this does not save the first file.  Its changes remain inside Emacs,
in that file's buffer.  The creation or editing of the second file's[K
buffer has no effect on the first file's buffer.  This is very useful,
but it also means that you need a convenient way to save the first[23;29H[7m51% L571[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lbuffer has no effect on the first file's buffer.  This is very useful,
but it also means that you need a convenient way to save the first
file's buffer.  Having to switch back to that buffer, in order to save
it with C-x C-s, would be a nuisance.  So we have[K
[K
        C-x s     Save some buffers[K
[K
C-x s asks you about each buffer which contains changes that you have
not saved.  It asks you, for each such buffer, whether to save the
buffer.[K
[K
>> Insert a line of text, then type C-x s.[14;4HIt should ask you whether to save the buffer named TUTORIAL.
   Answer yes to the question by typing "y".[K

AS* EXTENDING THE COMMAND SET[K
---------------------------[K
[K
There are many, many more Emacs commands than could possibly be put[K
on all the control and meta characters.  Emacs gets around this with[23;30H[7m3% L590[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lThere are many, many more Emacs commands than could possibly be put[K
on all the control and meta characters.  Emacs gets around this with
the X (eXtend) command.  This comes in two flavors:[K
[K
	C-x     Character eXtend.  Followed by one character.
	M-x     Named command eXtend.  Followed by a long name.

These are commands that are generally useful but are used less than the
commands you have already learned about.  You have already seen a few
of them: the file commands C-x C-f to Find and C-x C-s to Save, for
example.  Another example is the command to end the Emacs
session--this is the command C-x C-c.  (Do not worry about losing
changes you have made; C-x C-c offers to save each changed file before
it kills Emacs.)[K

If you are using a graphical display, you don't need any special
command to move from Emacs to another application.  You can do this
with the mouse or with window manager commands.  However, if you're
using a text terminal which can only show one application at a time,
you need to "suspend" Emacs to move to any other application.[K
[K[23;30H[7m4% L609[0m[39;49m[27m[H
[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lbuffer has no effect on the first file's buffer.  This is very useful,
but it also means that you need a convenient way to save the first[K
file's buffer.  Having to switch back to that buffer, in order to save
it with C-x C-s, would be a nuisance.  So we have
[K
	C-x s     Save some buffers[K

C-x s asks you about each buffer which contains changes that you have[K
not saved.  It asks you, for each such buffer, whether to save the[K
buffer.[K
[K
>> Insert a line of text, then type C-x s.[K
   It should ask you whether to save the buffer named TUTORIAL.[K
   Answer yes to the question by typing "y".

[1m[32m3 Keys[0m[39;49m[K
******
[K
Some Emacs commands are invoked by just one input event; for example,
`C-f' moves forward one character in the buffer.  Other commands take
two or more input events to invoke, such as `C-x C-f' and `C-x 4 C-f'.

   A "key sequence", or "key" for short, is a sequence of one or more
input events that is meaningful as a unit.  If a key sequence invokes a
command, we call it a "complete key"; for example, `C-f', `C-x C-f' and
`C-x 4 C-f' are all complete keys.  If a key sequence isn't long enough
to invoke a command, we call it a "prefix key"; from the preceding[K
example, we see that `C-x' and `C-x 4' are prefix keys.  Every key
sequence is either a complete key or a prefix key.[K
[K
   A prefix key combines with the following input event to make a
longer key sequence.  For example, `C-x' is a prefix key, so typing
`C-x' alone does not invoke a command; instead, Emacs waits for further[23;29H[7m[1mKeys[0m[39;49m[27m[7m   Top L2     (Info Narrow) [0m[39;49m[27m[4;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;41H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[5;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[3d[?25llonger key sequence.  For example, `C-x' is a prefix key, so typing[K
`C-x' alone does not invoke a command; instead, Emacs waits for further
input (if you pause for longer than a second, it echoes the `C-x' key
to prompt for that input; see [4m[34mEcho Area[0m[39;49m).  `C-x' combines with the
next input event to make a two-event key sequence, which could itself
be a prefix key (such as `C-x 4'), or a complete key (such as `C-x[K
C-f').  There is no limit to the length of key sequences, but in[K
practice they are seldom longer than three or four input events.[K[12;4HYou can't add input events onto a complete key.  For example,[K
because `C-f' is a complete key, the two-event sequence `C-f C-k' is[K
two key sequences, not one.[K
[K
   By default, the prefix keys in Emacs are `C-c', `C-h', `C-x', `C-x
<RET>', `C-x @', `C-x a', `C-x n', `C-x r', `C-x v', `C-x 4', `C-x 5',
`C-x 6', <ESC>, `M-g', and `M-o'.  (<F1> and <F2> are aliases for `C-h'
and `C-x 6'.)  This list is not cast in stone; if you customize Emacs,
you can make new prefix keys.  You could even eliminate some of the
standard ones, though this is not recommended for most users; for[K
example, if you remove the prefix definition of `C-x 4', then `C-x 4[K[23;36H[7m35% L19[0m[39;49m[27m[H

[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lstandard ones, though this is not recommended for most users; for[K
example, if you remove the prefix definition of `C-x 4', then `C-x 4[K
C-f' becomes an invalid key sequence.  See [4m[34mKey Bindings[0m[39;49m.[K
[K
   Typing the help character (`C-h' or <F1>) after a prefix key[K
displays a list of the commands starting with that prefix.  The sole
exception to this rule is <ESC>: `<ESC> C-h' is equivalent to `C-M-h',
which does something else entirely.  You can, however, use <F1> to
display a list of commands starting with <ESC>.

[1m[36m48.3 Customizing Key Bindings[0m[39;49m[K
=============================
[K
This section describes "key bindings", which map keys to commands, and
"keymaps", which record key bindings.  It also explains how to[K
customize key bindings, which is done by editing your init file (see
[4m[34mInit Rebinding[0m[39;49m).[K

[1m48.3.10 Rebinding Mouse Buttons[0m[K
-------------------------------[K
[K
Emacs uses Lisp symbols to designate mouse buttons, too.  The ordinary
mouse events in Emacs are "click" events; these happen when you press a
button and release it without moving the mouse.  You can also get[K
"drag" events, when you move the mouse while holding the button down.
Drag events happen when you finally let go of the button
[K
   The symbols for basic click events are `mouse-1' for the leftmost
button, `mouse-2' for the next, and so on.  Here is how you can[K
redefine the second mouse button to split the current window:[K
[K[18;6H(global-set-key [mouse-2] 'split-window-below)[20;4HThe symbols for drag events are similar, but have the prefix `drag-'
before the word `mouse'.  For example, dragging the first button
generates a `drag-mouse-1' event.
     [7m[1mMouse Buttons[0m[39;49m[27m[7m   Top L2     (Info Narrow) [0m[39;49m[27m[4;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;50H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[5;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;50H[?25l[7m4[0m[39;49m[27m[6;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;50H[?25l[7m5[0m[39;49m[27m[7;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;50H[?25l[7m6[0m[39;49m[27m[8;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;50H[?25l[7m7[0m[39;49m[27m[9;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[3d[?25lbefore the word `mouse'.  For example, dragging the first button[K
generates a `drag-mouse-1' event.
[K
   You can also define bindings for events that occur when a mouse
button is pressed down.  These events start with `down-' instead of
`drag-'.  Such events are generated only if they have key bindings.[K
When you get a button-down event, a corresponding click or drag event[K
will always follow.[K
[K
   If you wish, you can distinguish single, double, and triple clicks.
A double click means clicking a mouse button twice in approximately the
same place.  The first click generates an ordinary click event.  The
second click, if it comes soon enough, generates a double-click event
instead.  The event type for a double-click event starts with
`double-': for example, `double-mouse-3'.
[K[19;4HThis means that you can give a special meaning to the second click at
the same place, but it must act on the assumption that the ordinary[K
single click definition has run when the first click was received.
[K[23;45H[7m16% L19[0m[39;49m[27m[H

[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lsingle click definition has run when the first click was received.
[K[5;4HThis constrains what you can do with double clicks, but user
interface designers say that this constraint ought to be followed in
any case.  A double click should do something similar to the single
click, only "more so".  The command for the double-click event should
perform the extra work for the double click.[K
[K[11;4HIf a double-click event has no binding, it changes to the
corresponding single-click event.  Thus, if you don't define a[K
particular double click specially, it executes the single-click command
twice.[K
[K
   Emacs also supports triple-click events whose names start with
[Ctriple-'.  Emacs does not distinguish quadruple clicks as event types;
clicks beyond the third generate additional triple-click events.
However, the full number of clicks is recorded in the event list, so if[K
you know Emacs Lisp you can distinguish if you really want to (see[K
[4m[34mClick Events[0m[39;49m(elisp).).  We don't recommend distinct[K
meanings for more than three clicks, but sometimes it is useful for[23;45H[7m33% L37[0m[39;49m[27m[H

   This means that you can give a special meaning to the second click at
the same place, but it must act on the assumption that the ordinary
single click definition has run when the first click was received.
[K
   This constrains what you can do with double clicks, but user[K
interface designers say that this constraint ought to be followed in
any case.  A double click should do something similar to the single
click, only "more so".  The command for the double-click event should
perform the extra work for the double click.[K
[K
   If a double-click event has no binding, it changes to the[K
corresponding single-click event.  Thus, if you don't define a[K
particular double click specially, it executes the single-click command
twice.[K

   Emacs also supports triple-click events whose names start with[K
`triple-'.  Emacs does not distinguish quadruple clicks as event types;
clicks beyond the third generate additional triple-click events.[K[23;45H[7m30% L52[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[3d[K[4;6H[?25l(global-set-key [mouse-2] 'split-window-below)
[K
   The symbols for drag events are similar, but have the prefix `drag-'
before the word `mouse'.  For example, dragging the first button[K
generates a `drag-mouse-1' event.
[K
   You can also define bindings for events that occur when a mouse[K
button is pressed down.  These events start with `down-' instead of
`drag-'.  Such events are generated only if they have key bindings.[K
When you get a button-down event, a corresponding click or drag event
will always follow.
[K
   If you wish, you can distinguish single, double, and triple clicks.
A double click means clicking a mouse button twice in approximately the
same place.  The first click generates an ordinary click event.  The
second click, if it comes soon enough, generates a double-click event
instead.  The event type for a double-click event starts with[K
[Cdouble-': for example, `double-mouse-3'.[K

[1m48.3.10 Rebinding Mouse Buttons[0m
-------------------------------[K
[K
Emacs uses Lisp symbols to designate mouse buttons, too.  The ordinary
mouse events in Emacs are "click" events; these happen when you press a
button and release it without moving the mouse.  You can also get[K
"drag" events, when you move the mouse while holding the button down.
Drag events happen when you finally let go of the button.[K
[K
   The symbols for basic click events are `mouse-1' for the leftmost
button, `mouse-2' for the next, and so on.  Here is how you can
redefine the second mouse button to split the current window:[K
[K
     (global-set-key [mouse-2] 'split-window-below)[K
[K
   The symbols for drag events are similar, but have the prefix `drag-'
before the word `mouse'.  For example, dragging the first button
generates a `drag-mouse-1' event.[23;45H[7mTop L20[0m[39;49m[27m[A[?12l[?25h[?12;25h

[1m[32m19 Using Multiple Buffers[0m[39;49m[K
[C************************[K

The text you are editing in Emacs resides in an object called a
"buffer".  Each time you visit a file, a buffer is used to hold the[K
file's text.  Each time you invoke Dired, a buffer is used to hold the
directory listing.  If you send a message with `C-x m', a buffer is[K
used to hold the text of the message.  When you ask for a command's
documentation, that appears in a buffer named `*Help*'.[K
[K
   Each buffer has a unique name, which can be of any length.  When a[K
buffer is displayed in a window, its name is shown in the mode line
(see [4m[34mMode Line[0m[39;49m).  The distinction between upper and lower case
matters in buffer names.  Most buffers are made by visiting files, and
their names are derived from the files' names; however, you can also[K
create an empty buffer with any name you want.  A newly started Emacs
has several buffers, including one named `*scratch*', which can be used
for evaluating Lisp expressions and is not associated with any file[23;29H[7m[1mBuffers[0m[39;49m[27m[7m   Top L2     (Info Narrow) [0m[39;49m[27m[4;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;44H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[5;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[3d[?25lhas several buffers, including one named `*scratch*', which can be used[K
for evaluating Lisp expressions and is not associated with any file
(see [4m[34mLisp Interaction[0m[39;49m).[K
[K[7;4HAt any time, one and only one buffer is "selected"; we call it the
"current buffer".  We sometimes say that a command operates on "the
buffer"; this really means that it operates on the current buffer.[K
When there is only one Emacs window, the buffer displayed in that[K
window is current.  When there are multiple windows, the buffer[K
displayed in the "selected window" is current.  See [4m[34mWindows[0m[39;49m.[K
[K[14;4HAside from its textual contents, each buffer records several pieces
of information, such as what file it is visiting (if any), whether it
is modified, and what major mode and minor modes are in effect (se
[4m[34mModes[0m[39;49m).  These are stored in "buffer-local variables"--variables that
can have a different value in each buffer.  See [4m[34mLocals[0m[39;49m.[K
[K
   A buffer's size cannot be larger than some maximum, which is defined
by the largest buffer position representable by "Emacs integers".  This
is because Emacs tracks buffer positions using that data type.  For[23;39H[7m33% L19[0m[39;49m[27m[H

[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[?25lby the largest buffer position representable by "Emacs integers".  This
is because Emacs tracks buffer positions using that data type.  For
typical 64-bit machines, this maximum buffer size is 2^61 - 2 bytes, or
about 2 EiB.  For typical 32-bit machines, the maximum is usually 2^29
- 2 bytes, or about 512 MiB.  Buffer sizes are also limited by the[K
amount of memory in the system.[K

[1m[36m19.4 Killing Buffers[0m[39;49m[K
====================[K
[K
If you continue an Emacs session for a while, you may accumulate a
large number of buffers.  You may then find it convenient to "kill" the
buffers you no longer need.  On most operating systems, killing a
buffer releases its space back to the operating system so that other
programs can use it.  Here are some commands for killing buffers:[K
[K
`C-x k BUFNAME <RET>'[K
     Kill buffer BUFNAME (`kill-buffer').[K
[K
`M-x kill-some-buffers'[K
     Offer to kill each buffer, one by one.[K
[K
`M-x kill-matching-buffers'[K[21;6HOffer to kill all buffers matching a regular expression.[23;29H[7m[1mKill Buffer[0m[39;49m[27m[7m   Top L2     (Info Narrow) [0m[39;49m[27m[4;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[5;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m4[0m[39;49m[27m[6;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m5[0m[39;49m[27m[7;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m6[0m[39;49m[27m[8;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m7[0m[39;49m[27m[9;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m8[0m[39;49m[27m[10;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m9[0m[39;49m[27m[11;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;48H[?25l[7m10[0m[39;49m[27m[12;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m1[0m[39;49m[27m[13;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m2[0m[39;49m[27m[14;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m3[0m[39;49m[27m[15;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m4[0m[39;49m[27m[16;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m5[0m[39;49m[27m[17;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m6[0m[39;49m[27m[18;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m7[0m[39;49m[27m[19;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m8[0m[39;49m[27m[20;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h[23;49H[?25l[7m9[0m[39;49m[27m[21;1H[?12l[?25h[?12;25h

[1m[32m20 Multiple Windows[0m[39;49m[K
[C******************[K
[K
Emacs can split a frame into two or many windows.  Multiple windows can
display parts of different buffers, or different parts of one buffer.
Multiple frames always imply multiple windows, because each frame has
its own set of windows.  Each window belongs to one and only one frame.
[K

`Mouse-1'
     `Mouse-1', in the text area of a window, selects the window and

     selects the window without moving point in it.[K

   With the keyboard, you can switch windows by typing `C-x o'[K

are more than two windows, this command moves through all the windows
in a cyclic order, generally top to bottom and left to right.
